title.narrative: 6.3 JUSTICE AND SECURITY SERVICES

description.narrative: Output 6.3: By 2018, children and adolescents in contact with the justice system have access to services that guarantee their protection and the respect of their rights, in compliance with international norms, which contributes to Access To Justice, Justice For Children. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 6: By 2018, children and adolescents, particularly the most vulnerable, are better protected against abuse, violence and exploitation.

participating-org.narrative: DREP DOSSO DREP MINISTERE DE LENSEIGNEMENT PRIMAIRE

sector.narrative: Access to child-friendly police and justice sector services
Justice sector workforce strengthening and capacity building (including police)
Promoting diversion and alternatives to deprivation of liberty

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order policy, planning and administration

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 6.3: By 2018, children and adolescents in contact with the justice system have access to services that guarantee theirprotection and the respect of their rights, in compliance with international norms

description.narrative: Around 500 children in contact with the law benefited from services through specific training child protection and justice for children to judicial and social services. A unit for the protection of women and minors within the National Gendarmerie was created contributing to improve the coverage of specialized Security force. | Status:Met | As-of Date:31/01/2019

title.narrative: % of Juvenile Police Units/ Defence and Security Forces (DFS) focal points meeting basic requirements (trained personnel, regular submission of data)
% of juvenile courts implementing alternatives to incarceration

% of juvenile courts meeting basic requirements (with trained judge, prosecutor, court-appointed lawyer, court clerk, and High Court social workers), local committees meeting to manage cases at least once per month
% of juvenile quarters meeting basic requirements (trained personnel, and care and reintegration programme)
Existence of procedures and services for children in contact with law that are applied and delivered in line with international norms
Existence of specialized justice for children systems, such as capacity building and standards-setting within criminal and civil justice systems
